urls.title: ‘The Mezzotint' by M.R. James
urls.description: Introduction by Dan Coxon That Montague Rhodes James was one of the finest writers of supernatural fiction we’ve ever had is surely now beyond dispute. Of all his stories, ‘The Mezzotint’ is the one that I return to most often. In many ways it’s an archetypal James story: in his own words, he felt the two elements a ghost story should have were ‘atmosphere and the nicely-managed crescendo’, and he achieves both here with admirable efficiency. Where ‘The Mezzotint’ really scores for me, though, i

@adamsimcox #TheWitchFarm is great, isn't it! Makes Mondays worthwhile...
Loving this! (It includes my story 'Come Sing for the Harrowing', possibly the most folk-horror title I've written...) https://t.co/cnwGBI78kW

Bill's hands, the changing temperatures, the sulphurous smell, the dowsing rods. Maybe even the 'footsteps' on the stairs, as the sudden extreme heat (or cooling) caused the wood to contract or expand. The non-physical phenomena can all be explained by anxiety and sleep loss.

It might even explain the animal deaths and strange behaviour. So what do you think? Might there have been a damaged and accidentally grounded cable the power company didn't detect? If so it explains a lot of the phenomena...

Some further research... and if this HAD happened (and especially if the current was jumping from one object to another, called 'arcing') then it could produce heat and - wait for it - a sulphorous, eggy smell.

Which got me thinking about where this all started - the high electricity bill. I did some research, and if the main cable was frayed or damaged and accidentally grounded through the walls, metal fuse box, etc then it might create an EMF. And a strong one at that.

Obviously they were too far away for Chernobyl to do that... BUT a strong electromagnetic field also gives out radiation, and something clicked. Dowsing rods are often said to detect strong EMFs, which can cause headaches, sleeplessness, anxiety, paranoia... sound familiar?

Hi @danny_robins. Loving #TheWitchFarm but Bill's cracked hands got me thinking. Followed a bit of a rabbit hole here, but stick with me. It started when Chernobyl was mentioned - what he had on his hands almost sounds like low level radiation burns.
Oh ffs. https://t.co/ybguq0Rf8M

urls.title: Akira Kurosawa | BFI Southbank
urls.description: Your shopping basket is empty. Akira Kurosawa was always more than the sum of his samurai and action films, as this complete retrospective of his work as a director highlights. ‘The term “giant” is used too often to describe artists. But in the case of Akira Kurosawa, we have one of the rare instances where the term fits.’ – Martin Scorsese Like a gathering storm, much of Kurosawa’s cinema begins with a portent of the turbulence to come. But within his work lay a poetry – both in his visual style and the

urls.title: Londongrad
urls.description: Will Coxon looks at the extent of money from Russian oligarchs in London, suggesting why regulation of foreign investment is needed. Londongrad, a 2015 Russian crime comedy television series about Russian expats living in London, opens its premiere episode introducing the drunk Oleg Dorokhov. Oleg often violates numerous laws of the United Kingdom but manages to avoid justice for three reasons. Reason number one is that Oleg has a lot of money. Reason number two is that Oleg’s father’s love for him is

tweets.text: It might even explain the animal deaths and strange behaviour. So what do you think? Might there have been a damaged and accidentally grounded cable the power company didn't detect? If so it explains a lot of the phenomena...

Some further research... and if this HAD happened (and especially if the current was jumping from one object to another, called 'arcing') then it could produce heat and - wait for it - a sulphorous, eggy smell.

Which got me thinking about where this all started - the high electricity bill. I did some research, and if the main cable was frayed or damaged and accidentally grounded through the walls, metal fuse box, etc then it might create an EMF. And a strong one at that.

Obviously they were too far away for Chernobyl to do that... BUT a strong electromagnetic field also gives out radiation, and something clicked. Dowsing rods are often said to detect strong EMFs, which can cause headaches, sleeplessness, anxiety, paranoia... sound familiar?

Hi @danny_robins. Loving #TheWitchFarm but Bill's cracked hands got me thinking. Followed a bit of a rabbit hole here, but stick with me. It started when Chernobyl was mentioned - what he had on his hands almost sounds like low level radiation burns.
@DanCoxonAuthor It's absolutely shite. Haha

When I need a character name, I look at my bookshelves. This week, @DanCoxonAuthor's Isolation anthology keeps catching my eye, resulting in a string of Dans, Dons, Daniels, Cottons, Caxtons, etc across various projects. Sorry for the terrible treatment of your namesakes Dan.

Wonderful news - I now have an agent! I asked for recommendations recently and several people (writers and editors alike) named @a_cochran as being super lovely. 

With his interest in crossover genres, hopefully he’ll help me balance my love of horror AND dark fantasy!
